author: USA TODAY
title: Building iPhones in U.S. is non-starter, says ex-Foxconn exec
text:
Building iPhones in U.S. is non-starter, says ex-Foxconn exec Jon Swartz   12:57 p.m.   12 minutes ago 
President Trump in the Oval Office on Jan. 23, 2017. (Photo: Nicholas Kamm, AFP/Getty Images) 
SAN FRANCISCO — President Trump dreams of gold-plated U.S. companies planting major manufacturing facilities in the American heartland, pumping out smartphones, cars and other goods. 
Dream on. 
Even in the face of what Trump calls a "very major border tax" to create more factory jobs in the U.S., most tech hardware makers aren't likely to raise stakes at offshore operations and come home. 
It's simple — do the math, says Dan Panzica, a senior principal analyst at market researcher IHS Markit who previously was vice president of engineering at Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics maker and a major assembler of iPhones. 
Calculate steeper labor costs for American workers. Recruit and train assemblers in mass numbers. Import key components to make product. And, oh, spend a few billion dollars here or there building automated facilities like those in China and elsewhere to mass-produce iPhones. 
“Production was never here (for major consumer-electronics assembly). There is no infrastructure,” Panzica says. To meet production of more than 200 million iPhones sold annually requires tens of thousands of people, working around the clock, in specialized facilities. “No U.S. city could handle that,” Panzica says. 
He conceded Apple could do final assembly of a limited edition iPhone in Texas, for instance, to satisfy Trump. Higher labor costs would be offset by savings in transportation expenses, he says. Apple iPhone sales by year 2007-2016 | Statista 
Apple had no comment. 
"Nanufacturing iPhones in the U.S. would be cool, but it won't make any difference to the employment problem in the Midwest," says Roger McNamee, founding partner at venture-capital firm Elevation Partners. "The union jobs in the upper Midwest have been gone for a generation. They left for the Sun Belt under Presidents Reagan and George H.W. Bush. The Sun Belt manufacturing jobs that replaced them are non-union, pay much less well, have lower benefits, etc."
